questions.question: I ………………. the papers to his office.
questions.description: We use bring for movements to the place where the speaker or the listener is. We use take for movements to other places.

questions.question: This is a lovely beach. Thanks for ………………… me here.
questions.description: We use bring for movements to the place where the speaker or the listener is. We use take for movements to other places.

questions.question: ……………….. like swimming.
questions.description: Before a noun with a determiner, both and both of are both possible.

questions.question: I …………….. my camera to James and I never saw it again.
questions.description: To lend is to give. You lend something to somebody.

questions.question: What are the main differences ………………….. dogs, wolves and foxes?
questions.description: We use between, not among, after difference.

questions.question: I had ……………… unpleasant experience in the morning.
questions.description: A little and a bit are not used with adjectives in attributive position.

questions.question: American football is very different ……………. soccer.
questions.description: From and to are common in British English and than is common in American English.

questions.question: At no time ……………… her self-control.
questions.description: If a negative adverb comes at the beginning of a clause, it is usually followed by auxiliary verb + subject.

questions.question: I ………………. going to new places and meeting new people.
questions.description: Very much does not come between like and its object.

questions.question: A crocodile starts life ………….. an egg.
Could you ……………. if dad is in the garage?
questions.description: Before ‘if’ we can use ‘see’ or ‘look to see’. Look is not used before if or whether.
